body:
_From @dmarvp on July 5, 2018 15:37_

Btw, this seems somewhat related to #5523 and similar to this 2-year old issue in stack overflow: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34794516/gcloud-python-close-connection
Seems this should maybe be moved to gRPC, @tseaver?

_From @tseaver on July 9, 2018 17:45_

@theacodes You likely know better than I. :)
@theacodes Does closing the `Channel` instances via the fairly recently-introduced `Channel.close` API (or a `with` statement, if applicable) help by any chance?
That's a good question for @dmarvp.
You should be able to close the channel with `client.channel.close()` or `client._channel.close()`.

@mehrdada @theacodes thanks for your help. I can't use a with statement on the SpeechClient (it doesn't support it) and it doesn't look as if it has the channel or _channel properties. Maybe it's the version of the package I'm using, here's the output from pip freeze:


Do I need to upgrade grpcio, google-cloud-speech or any other library to an specific version to try this?

Nevermind, I updated google-cloud-speech to the latest version 0.35.0, added the channel.close() calls and these are the results after using the client twice:
```
[root@750bd25bf23f virtual-device]# netstat -a
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State      
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:hbci            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp        0      0 750bd25bf23f:53134      mia09s18-in-f10.1:https ESTABLISHED
tcp        0      0 750bd25bf23f:59032      yyz08s09-in-f13.1:https ESTABLISHED
tcp        1      0 750bd25bf23f:35766      mia07s35-in-f109.:https CLOSE_WAIT 
tcp        0      0 750bd25bf23f:59022      yyz08s09-in-f13.1:https ESTABLISHED
tcp        0      0 750bd25bf23f:hbci       gateway:36026           ESTABLISHED
tcp       46      0 750bd25bf23f:53144      mia09s18-in-f10.1:https ESTABLISHED
Active UNIX domain sockets (servers and established)
Proto RefCnt Flags       Type       State         I-Node   Path
```
Seven minutes later:
```
[root@750bd25bf23f virtual-device]# netstat -a
Active Internet connections (servers and established)
Proto Recv-Q Send-Q Local Address           Foreign Address         State      
tcp        0      0 0.0.0.0:hbci            0.0.0.0:*               LISTEN     
tcp        1      0 750bd25bf23f:59032      yyz08s09-in-f13.1:https CLOSE_WAIT 
tcp        1      0 750bd25bf23f:35766      mia07s35-in-f109.:https CLOSE_WAIT 
tcp        1      0 750bd25bf23f:59022      yyz08s09-in-f13.1:https CLOSE_WAIT 
Active UNIX domain sockets (servers and established)
Proto RefCnt Flags       Type       State         I-Node   Path
```
I don't know if that should be normal. Seems to be better than before but still present.
@theacodes Do you know if the `client.channel` is the only gRPC channel used by the library? Are there more (potentially short-lived ones that are never exposed as an attribute)

If that's the only client instance, that's the only channel.

The others open sockets *could* be from Requests' connection pool.

At the Core level, subchannels are pooled and reused, so this behavior might be entirely reasonable. @dmarvp Do you observe an unbounded increase of file descriptors or will it be a finite number of sockets in `CLOSE_WAIT` even when you call `Channel.close` explicitly? If not, I would not be too concerned about this.

@theacodes Is there a plan on the Cloud Libraries side to provide a `close` method on the client instance which explicitly calls `Channel.close`?

> @theacodes Is there a plan on the Cloud Libraries side to provide a close method on the client instance which explicitly calls Channel.close?

Not presently, but we do make the channel itself a public member.

@theacodes That may be something worthy of consideration. I think at this point we have recognized the lack of an explicit `close` method as a misstep in the original gRPC API design, causing reliability and debugging concerns, and we are actively encouraging all users to use `with`/`close`.
@dmarvp can you pl confirm if there is an unbounded increase in file descriptors?
@srini100 I've set the ulimit of my container to 1024 and I'm currently running a batch of 1100 requests against my service. Will report back with the results.

@srini100 , @mehrdada 

So, I've been doing requests for a couple of hours now and after running

```
 netstat -ant | awk '{print $6}' | sort | uniq -c | sort -n
```

I have the following number of open connections (grouped by state)

```
1 Foreign
1 LISTEN
1 established)
25 TIME_WAIT
49 ESTABLISHED
1008 CLOSE_WAIT
```
So, I think that the problem persists, even after explicitly closing the channel.
@dmarvp, thanks for confirming. Looks like a bug. We'll try to reproduce this at gRPC level. Can you by any chance be able to repro just with gRPC. It'll help us resolve this faster. Thanks.
@srini100 Sorry, I wouldn't know how to do it. I'm getting the error through the use of the google speech library. Haven't really worked just with grpc alone before.

@theacodes, I believe the issue is due to not closing the gRPC channel explicitly. For a long running client that opens connections constantly, it seems normal to see many sockets in CLOSE_WAIT until the garbage collector cleans up the out of scope channels. By enabling GRPC_VERBOSITY=debug GRPC_TRACE=fd_trace, I can see this when explicitly closing the channel:
(fd-trace) fd_create(9, tcp-client:ipv6:[::1]:50051, 0)
(fd-trace) fd_shutdown(9)
(fd-trace) grpc_fd_orphan, fd:9 closed

Without explicit close, last two lines are missing.

@dmarvp, can you please run with these envn variables set and send us the trace?
GRPC_VERBOSITY=debug GRPC_TRACE=fd_trace,client_channel,tcp,api

The logs look fine. You can see that one fd was opened and closed for this call.
The open call
(fd-trace) fd_create(10, tcp-client:ipv4:172.217.15.202:443)
is matched by corresponding close.
(fd-trace) fd_shutdown(10)
(fd-trace) grpc_fd_orphan, fd:10 closed
The address matches yyz08s13-in-f141.1e100.net.

@theacodes, is it possible the library is opening another connection without a gRPC channel?

Yes, as mentioned our libraries use a standard http library (requests) to
send requests to refresh authentication credentials.

On Fri, Jul 27, 2018 at 11:32 AM Srini Polavarapu <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> The logs look fine. You can see that one fd was opened and closed for this
> call.
> The open call
>
>
> (fd-trace) fd_create(10, tcp-client:ipv4:172.217.15.202:443)
>
> is matched by corresponding close.
> (fd-trace) fd_shutdown(10)
>
>
> (fd-trace) grpc_fd_orphan, fd:10 closed
>
> The address matches yyz08s13-in-f141.1e100.net.
>
> @theacodes <https://github.com/theacodes>, is it possible the library is
> opening another connection without a gRPC channel?
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/15990#issuecomment-408503069>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAPUc4h9kWQn6otjgXwaJzxctK08xX8zks5uK1zTgaJpZM4VLuGt>
> .
>

@theacodes, closing this issue since there is no evidence of leak in gRPC. Please reopen https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/google-cloud-python/issues/5570 and investigate there. I also confirmed that not calling channel.close() does not leave sockets open. Did a stress test on this and didn't see any open sockets.
